note.p: Heavily revised draft, approximately eleven lines, of "Halcyon Days," which was first published in the 29 January 1888 issue of the New York Herald. One the reverse is a letter from Fred W. Waggert, dated "4th June 1887."

lg.head: Halcyon Days.

l.del: O for the happy and quiet days!
The teeming and blissful halcyon days!
When will they come? and where do they rise?

lg.l: Do they comeNot from successful love? alone,

Nor wealth, nor ‸honored ins middle age, nor victories
of politics or war

ButAs life wanes ‸submitting, adjusting itself
and submits — — as the sea of the turbulent
passions is calmesd
As the gorgeous and silent colors of sunset cover the ‸evening sky west

As thatan indescribable softness and rest
suffuses the spirit and frame, like
a fresher, balmier air.

As ‸the shortening days life takes on a mellower lightand hangs the apple furnished — onand the
ripe tree

E'en as the winter solstice is passing
or passed, and night ‸duly approaches,
Then for the happyiest and quietest days ‸of all!
The teeming ‸and brooding and blissful halcyon days!
